chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Cervical screening
chapter.summary: Covers information on which women should have cervical screening through the NHS Cervical Screening Programme and how often, when it should be delayed, and how a cervical sample should be taken.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 25 years to 65 years (Female).

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.fullItemName: Scenario: Managing HPV and cervical cytology results

subChapters.htmlHeader: Who should be called for routine cervical screening?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• The NHS Cervical Screening Programme (NHSCSP) offers screening for all women between the ages of 24.5 years and 64 years at different intervals depending on their age:
    • Age 24.5 years — first invitation to ensure women can be screened before they are aged 25 years.
    • Age 25–49 years — screening every 3 years. 
      • Once primary HPV screening has been fully implemented, this interval will be extended to every 5 years. 
    • Age 50–64 years — screening every 5 years.
    • Women 65 years of age or older are invited if: 
      • A recent cervical cytology sample is abnormal.
      • They have not had a cervical screening test since 50 years of age and they request one.
  • Women with cervical stenosis — refer to the colposcopy clinic for consideration of cervical dilatation.
  • Women with a cervix that cannot be visualized — refer for colposcopy.
  • Transgender men who have retained their cervix — these men should be included in the NHSSCP unless they have made an informed decision to opt out.
    • The GP should take responsibility for the screening process and notify the laboratory to return the results to the practice and not the call and recall service.
  • Non-binary individuals must be invited by the GP practice to participate — the current registration system is unable to record this gender category.
  • Women can withdraw from the programme voluntarily by written request. However, they should be provided with sufficient information to enable them to make an informed decision.
  • Unscheduled cervical screening does not form part of the NHSCSP unless the woman is immunosuppressed, where more frequent screening may be required. For more information, see the section on Cervical screening if immunosuppressed.
  • If the woman has symptoms or signs of possible gynaecological cancer, urgent referral and assessment of the cervix is required.
    • For more information, see the CKS topics on Cervical cancer and HPV, and Gynaecological cancers - recognition and referral.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on the Public Health England (PHE) guidelines NHS cervical screening programme: colposcopy and programme management [PHE, 2020] and NHS Cervical screening programme guidance for the training of cervical sample takers [PHE, 2016a], and The Green Book: human papillomavirus (HPV) [PHE, 2014].

Refer women with cervical stenosis to colposcopy

  • It may not be possible to obtain a cytology sample that represents the entire transformation zone from women who have severe cervical stenosis. Cervical dilatation may be required [PHE, 2016b].

subChapters.htmlHeader: When should cervical screening be delayed?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• A cervical sample should not be taken (unless you think the woman will not re-attend), if the woman:
    • Is menstruating.
    • Is less than 12 weeks postnatal.
    • Is less 12 weeks after a termination of pregnancy, or miscarriage.
    • Has a vaginal discharge or pelvic infection — treat the infection and take the sample on another occasion.
  • If the woman is pregnant, see the section on Cervical screening if pregnant.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the Public Health England (PHE) NHS Cervical Screening Programme: guidance for the training of cervical sample takers [PHE, 2016a].

subChapters.fullItemName: How to take a cytology sample
subChapters.htmlHeader: How do I take a cytology sample for cervical screening?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Before taking a cytology sample:
    • All healthcare professionals should ensure that they are competent to do so and have undergone the appropriate training.
    • All women should be given information and advice to enable them to make an informed choice about whether to accept the offer of screening.  
      • A patient information leaflet, NHS cervical screening: helping you decide is sent with screening invitations. It is available to download in a number of languages.
  • To take a cytology sample:
    • Visualize the cervix (using a speculum) — if the cervix appears abnormal, suggesting possible malignancy, arrange urgent referral (within 2 weeks) to a gynaecologist.
      • Note: there is no need for referral for colposcopy if there has been contact bleeding at the time a cervical sample is obtained (in the absence of other symptoms). For more information, see the Diagnosis and Referral sections in the CKS topic on Cervical cancer and HPV.
    • Take a sample from the whole of the transformation zone.
      • The transformation zone can be identified by visual inspection as there is a change in colour and texture from the pale, pink, shiny, smooth surface of the ectocervix to a reddish, granular appearance of the columnar cells that line the endocervical canal.
      • The position of the transformation zone may be affected by age and pregnancy.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on the Public Health England (PHE) guidelines NHS Cervical screening programme: guidance for the training of cervical sample takers [PHE, 2016a] and NHS cervical screening programme: colposcopy and programme management [PHE, 2016b], and a Canadian clinical guideline Cervical cancer screening [TOP, 2016].

  • Cytology samples are taken from the transformation zone because most cervical pre-cancer and cancer develops in the squamo-columnar junction. Cells in this area are always dividing and are at risk of abnormal changes [TOP, 2016].

subChapters.htmlHeader: Should a pregnant woman be offered cervical screening?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• If a woman has been called for routine screening and she is pregnant — reschedule the test for when she is at least 3 months post-partum.
  • If a previous test was abnormal and in the interim the woman becomes pregnant — colposcopy should not be delayed.
    • Women may undergo colposcopy in late first, or early second trimester, unless there is a clinical contraindication. However, for low-grade changes, the assessment may be delayed until after delivery.
    • Women seen in early pregnancy may require a further assessment in the late second trimester.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the Public Health England (PHE) guidelines NHS Cervical screening programme: guidance for the training of cervical sample takers [PHE, 2016a] and NHS cervical screening programme: colposcopy and programme management [PHE, 2016b].

subChapters.htmlHeader: Should women who have had a hysterectomy be offered cervical screening?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Women who have had a:
    • Subtotal hysterectomy (that still have a cervix) should continue in the National Cervical Screening Programme (NHSCSP).
    • Total hysterectomy (no longer have a cervix) are not required to take part in the NHSCSP.
      • After a hysterectomy, the secondary care team will decide what follow-up is required. The type and frequency of follow-up depend on the reason for the hysterectomy and if cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) was found in the hysterectomy specimen.
  • Women who have had a hysterectomy with CIN present are potentially at risk of developing vaginal intraepithelial neoplasia (VaIN) and invasive vaginal disease, the NHSCSP recommends the following follow up for women who have had a total hysterectomy:
    • Women on routine recall with no CIN in their hysterectomy specimen do not need further follow up.
    • Women not on routine recall with no CIN in their hysterectomy specimen should have vault cytology 6 months after surgery.
      • If this is negative, no further screening is necessary.
    • Women with CIN which has been completely excised should be offered vault cytology 6 and 18 months after surgery.
      • If test results are negative at both time points, no further follow up is necessary.
    • Women with CIN which has not been completely excised, or excision is uncertain, should be followed up as if their cervix remained in situ and offered:
      • If high-grade disease (CIN 2 or CIN 3): cytology at 6, and 12 months, followed by annual cytology for 9 years (follow up continues to age 65 years, or until 10 years after surgery, whichever is later). 
      • If low-grade disease (CIN 1): cytology at 6, 12, and 24 months.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the Public Health England (PHE) guideline NHS cervical screening programme: colposcopy and programme management [PHE, 2016b].

subChapters.htmlHeader: Should women who are immunosuppressed be offered more frequent cervical screening?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Offer cervical screening to women aged 25–65 years: 
    • With kidney failure who require dialysis (or any other disease with a high chance of needing organ transplantation) at, or shortly after diagnosis.
    • Who are about to undergo organ transplantation within a year before transplantation.
    • Who are starting cytotoxic drugs for rheumatological disorders if the screening history is incomplete at the start of treatment.
      • Any abnormality should be referred immediately to colposcopy.
    • Who are HIV positive at diagnosis and annually thereafter. Ideally, colposcopy should also be offered at diagnosis.
  • There is no indication for increased surveillance in women taking:
    • Post-transplantation immunosuppressive drugs after the first year in women with no history of cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN). However, a woman with an abnormal cervical cytology result should be referred promptly for colposcopy. 
    • Cytotoxic chemotherapy for non-genital cancers.
    • Oestrogen antagonists (such as tamoxifen).
    • Cytotoxic drugs for rheumatological disorders or biologic agents for other disorders.
    • Alemtuzumab.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the Public Health England (PHE) guideline NHS cervical screening programme: colposcopy and programme management [PHE, 2016b].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How often should women who have been treated for CIN be offered cervical screening?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• It is important to encourage women to attend follow up, as women treated for cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) are at increased risk of developing cervical cancer.
  • All women treated for CIN should be followed up for test of cure cervical cytology 6 months after treatment.
    • If the sample is negative, borderline or low-grade, a reflex high-risk human papillomavirus (HR–HPV) test should be taken.
      • Women who are HPV positive should be referred for colposcopy.
      • Women who are HPV negative should be recalled for repeated cytology in 3 years, irrespective of their age. 
    • If the sample is high-grade dyskaryosis or invasive squamous carcinoma, the woman should be referred for colposcopy. An HR-HPV test is unnecessary.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN)
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) is a premalignant lesion, detected by colposcopy.
  • It may exist at any one of three stages, and is graded depending on how deep the cell changes go into the surface of the cervix:
    • CIN1 — one-third of the thickness of the surface layer of the cervix is affected.
    • CIN2 — two-thirds of the thickness of the surface layer of the cervix is affected.
    • CIN3 — sometimes called high-grade or severe dysplasia or stage 0 cervical carcinoma in situ. The full thickness of the surface layer is affected.
  • Left untreated, CIN2 or CIN3 (collectively referred to as CIN2+) may progress to cervical cancer. 
  • Usually (for all three grades) only a small part of the cervix has abnormal changes.

[Macmillan Cancer Support, 2013; WHO, 2013; PHE, 2016a]

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on the Public Health England (PHE) guideline NHS cervical screening programme: colposcopy and programme management [PHE, 2016b], and NHS Cervical screening programme guidance for the training of cervical sample takers [PHE, 2016a].

Follow up of women treated for CIN [PHE, 2016b]

  • Women who have been treated for CIN are 2–5 times more likely than the general population to develop cervical cancer, which may result from poor compliance with long term follow up. 
    • Several case series demonstrate that over 50% of cancers develop in women who are lost to follow up.
